facts.text: Appeal by special leave against judgment dated August 12, 1969 of Delhi High Court (Himachal Bench) in Criminal Appeal No. 68 of 1967 and Murder Reference No. 1 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 67 of 1969. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 12, 1969 of the Delhi High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 68 of 1967 and Murder Reference No. 1 of 1967.

facts.text: High Court acquitted the accused who had been sentenced to death for murder under Section 302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: R. Khanna and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant. Har Pershad and O. N. Mohindroo, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Jaganmohan Reddy, J. This Appeal is by Special leave against the Judgment of the Himachal Bench of The High Court of Delhi acquitting the accused who had been sentenced to death for an offence of murder under Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Accused was Manager at Kotkhai Branch of Himachal Pradesh State Cooperative Bank; deceased Sunder Lal Chaturvedi was General Manager.

anchor.surface_text: The accused Respondent was a Manager at the Kotkhai Branch of the Himachal Pradesh State Cooperative Bank of which Sunder Lal Chaturvedi the deceased was the General Manager.

facts.text: Fire in Kotkhai Branch, records burnt, Rs. 10,000 missing; accused suspended then dismissed by deceased.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that during the period the accused was working in that Bank there was a fire in the Kotkhai Branch in which the records of the Bank were burnt and a sum of Rs. 10,000/,A was found missing. The deceased had suspended the accused from the service and subsequently he was dismissed.

facts.text: Deceased retired in 1964, started Himprasth Financiers Pvt Ltd in 1965, Managing Director, lived in Nagina Singh Building, Shimla.

anchor.surface_text: In or about 1964, the deceased retired from the Bank and in 1965 started a Private Limited Company under the name of Himprasth Financiers with the Head Office at Nagina Singh Building which was situated in the Mall at Shimla of which he was the Managing Director. He used to also live in the same building in one of the rooms of the office

facts.text: Accused appointed accountant in Finance Company, resigned by letter dated 31-12-1966, accepted 3-1-1967.

anchor.surface_text: After the accused was dismissed from the Bank he had applied to the deceased for a job and was appointed as an Accountant in the Finance Company but later when his request for increase in his pay was number sanctioned, he sent in his resignation by a letter dated 31- 12-66 Exh. P. 8 and it was accepted on 3-1-67 by a resolution of the Board of Directors Exh. P. 43.

facts.text: On night of 30 January 1967, deceased had dinner at Mansarovar Hotel, met accused witnessed by PW7 Romesh Chand, seen by PW9 Lal Chand at betel shop going towards Nagina Singh Building.

anchor.surface_text: On the night of 30th January 1967 the deceased had his dinner at the Hotel and when lie came out after taking his food it was alleged that he was met by the accused. This was witnessed by Romesh Chand P.W. 7 the Proprietor of the Hotel who saw them both going towards the Mall. Thereafter at the betel shop which is near Nagina Singh Building, Lal Chand P.W. 9 who was purchasing cigarettes at that shop saw them together and going towards the Nagina Singh Building.

facts.text: 31 January 1967, 9:30 a.m., PW2 I.C. Gupta found deceased lying in pool of blood, door bolted inside, called police.

anchor.surface_text: On the 31st January 67 at about 9.30 a.m. I. C. Gupta P.W. 2, came to visit the deceased and .found that the main door was bolted from inside. He then peeped through the glass of the window panes through the adjoining room and saw that the deceased was lying in a pool of blood. He immediately telephoned to the Police.

facts.text: SHO PW28 Inder Raj Malik arrived, broke open room, found 4 incised wounds on deceased, blood-stained key Ex.4, coat button Ex.1 under table, finger impressions on flask and glass pane, blood wiped on curtain.

anchor.surface_text: In response to this call the Station House Officer of the Saddar Police Station, Inder Raj Malik, P.W. 28 came to the building, broke open the room through the kitchen door and saw that the back door of the bath room was open. ... The deceased had on him four incised wounds one on the neck and 3 on the hands. On inspection of the room he found on the nearby table a key Ex. 4 stained with blood and under the table there was a biscuit companyour Coat button Ex. 1.

facts.text: Missing items: two loan registers, one general ledger, one cash book, vouchers April 66 to Dec 66, one blanket, one tea-poy, one canvas bag.

anchor.surface_text: These three persons informed him after inspection list two loan registers, one general ledger, one cash book and vouchers from April 66 to December 66 were missing. They further informed him that one blanket of the deceased, one tea-poy companye, and one canvas bag was missing.

facts.text: On 1 Feb 1967, accused arrested at his house in Anandale, pursuant to his statement, seized sweater, coat, blanket from his room, boots and socks he was wearing.

anchor.surface_text: On 1-2-6- at about 11.30 a.m. P.W. 28 accompanied by the Assistant Sub-Inspector and Constables met P.W. 2, P.W. 8 and boarded the jeep of P.W. 2 driven by Roshan Lal and went towards the house of Om Prakash. ... After interrogating him he arrested him and pursuant to a statement made by him seized from him one sweater, one companyt, one blanket which was hidden inside the nivar of his company lying inside his room.

facts.text: Accused disclosed location of blood-stained dagger under stone slab below Maidan of Burnt Market, recovered in presence of witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The accused also gave them the pair of boots and socks which he was wearing and informed them that he had companycealed one blood stained dagger under a stone slab below the Maidan of Burnt Market and over the bakeries which was by the side of a pipe and offered to have it recovered.

facts.text: Accused stated he hid five registers in canvas bag below stone at Krishna Nagar on bank of Ganda Nala, threw 8-9 bundles of vouchers tied in tea-poy cloth and blood-stained pants in Ganda Nala.

anchor.surface_text: He further stated that he had kept the five registers in a canvas bag which lie had hidden below a stone at Krishna Nagar on the bank of Ganda Nala and that he had thrown 8 or 9 bundles of the vouchers tied in a tea-poy cloth and his blood stained pants in the Ganda Nala and would get them recovered.

facts.text: On 2 Feb 1967, recovered canvas bag with five registers, tea-poy cloth with vouchers, blood-stained pant from Ganda Nala.

anchor.surface_text: On the next day namely 2-2-67 P.W. 28, got a plan of the rooms and the office where the deceased was working and living prepared and from there accompanied by P.W. 2, P.W. 13 went to Krishna Nagar ... From near there the accused pointed out a stone slab from where a canvas bag which companytained five registers said to be missing from the residence of the deceased were recovered

facts.text: Forensic reports: human blood on key, dagger, blanket, coat, sweater, pant, shoes, socks; button similar to one on accused's coat.

anchor.surface_text: The Chemical Examiner and Serologist found human blood on the key. the dagger, blanket, companyt, sweater and pant, the shoes and socks. ... The button and the companyt were sent to the forensic laboratory at Chandigarh for examination. ... which gavel a report that it was similar to the button on the companyt from which it was missing.

facts.text: Finger print expert found impressions on flask and glass pane match accused's with more than 12 points of similarity.

anchor.surface_text: The finger print expert found on the flask and the glass pane reported as per Ex. P. 59 that they are the same as those of the accused and have more than 12 points of similarity i.e. matching ridge characteristic details.

facts.text: Accused purchased dagger from PW11 Ganga Singh on 30 Jan 1967.

anchor.surface_text: He then took them to the Tekri of one Ganga Singh P. W. II, in the Lower Bazar who sells daggers and there P.W. 28 recorded his statement that on the day of the incident the accused had purchased the dagger recovered from under the stone which was identified by P.W. 11, as the one sold to him.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court acquittal, convicts accused under Sec 302 IPC, sentences to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the evidence in this case is.- sufficient to justify the companyviction of the accused for an offence of murder. We, accordingly set aside the judgment of acquittal of the High Court, companyvict the accused under Sec. 302 and sentence him to life imprisonment.

facts.text: High Court rejected motive as accused was re-employed by deceased after dismissal.

issues.text: Whether the Supreme Court has power to interfere with the High Court's judgment of acquittal?

anchor.surface_text: Court has undoubted power to interfere with the findings of fact, no distinction being made between judgments of acquittal and conviction, though in the case of acquittals it will not ordinarily interfere with the appreciation cf evidence or on findings of fact unless the High Court acts perversely or otherwise improperly  See State of Madras v. Vaidyanatha lyer   1 .
